cons:
Middle Management and former Compaq values have destroyed the company. After the HP/Compaq merger, much of the Compaq management were put in charge of manufacturing & supply-chain decisions which put HP back 20 years in the streamlined processes, and ethical dealing, (i.e. supply-chain management accepted items which could be construed as 'gifts' which influenced decisions). When HP employees expressed better ways of doing things, they were threated with the jobs and told by the Compaq management, "We've Always Done Things, This Way". HP's open door policy was pushed aside, as the Compaq management talked out of both side of their mouths, saying they want to hear new ideas, and got angry when people did not follow, "The Chain of Command". Managers, not individual contributors, are rewarded significantly with bonuses when meeting 'metrics' that are mostly made up numbers, while individual contributors are told they must make those metrics or fear loosing their jobs. Little to no opportunity for advancement, as recruiters are compensated for hiring from outside the company, or if an employee does everything, (ethical or not), to make their management look good to get bonuses.
Advice to Management
Not sure if there is a chance to turn things around, even though a lot of middle management has been removed, but think it is a mistake moving the headquarters to Houston, where the values are not the same as Palo Alto had. Take away the bonus structure for management, and bring back the profit sharing program for all employees that is not tied to each business unit.

pros: They have good benefits like health insurance, wellness programs and paid maternity leave (but beware, you might get laid off upon return or even while pregnant, I know of one employee that got fired at 7 months of pregnant just for workforce reductions impact.
cons:
HP- HPE has been on a transformation journey for decades, and with that thousands of layoffs have been the constant. During almost 11 years I never felt any type of job security. I absorbed at one point 3 people’s jobs as they let them go and I started because I was ridiculously underpaid. 
There is no control over the amount of work or effort that it takes to do a certain role, so some people might be doing nothing while others are being overworked.

There’s no real career path, although they sell you that the sky is the limit, I was never longer than 2-3 years on a role before a new reorganization or transformation would hit and another arbitrary role would be assigned. 
Applying for jobs to try to move or escalate internally is all a lie. 
Roles are pretty much given by who you know, you will get interviews, because obviously there’s an HR process to follow, but they will ask you whatever just to make the “quota” and tell you that they selected someone else, and that you lacked skills that they did not even bother to ask if you had.
They keep bringing people from Dell, Cisco and other competitors hoping that they will provide competitive insight, and these people will start laying off people to bring in their new buddies and cycle starts.
Being a USA employee is really hard, as their location strategy is to send all to low cost countries. So most jobs in US tend to be moved to Mexico, India or Low Cost countries in Europe.
They also love to let go people with long careers in the Company, I am taking with about 20+ years, by forcing them on early retirement, regardless if they are ready or not. I know a bunch of people that went through it and are now trying to look for a job in their late 50’s early 60’s. A pretty bad way to thank loyal employees who invested their whole lives in the Company. 
They did change their benefits being really altruistic by offering 26 weeks of parental leave. All of this happened while I was already pregnant, so I was pretty exited about that! 
I came from maternity just to realize they had hired a replacement in a low cost country , and they laid me off a month an a half after returning from maternity leave.
I would not recommend this company to work for if you value yourself, and or if you are looking for career growth and stability.

Value the employees that are about to retire instead of getting rid of them.

pros: In its heyday, up until around 2006, HP was THE place to work. "The HP Way" was that management's job was to tell their people what the objective was, then "let them loose" to accomplish it. And it worked, exceedingly well. Management was there to provide support and enable their people. "Micro-management" didn't exist at HP. People felt proud to contribute, to "break rules" if needed, and innovation was a "given." Bill & Dave treated everyone as a friend or family. This type of managment was unheard of back when HP was just beginning, and at the time other CEOs literally laughed at their business model. They stopped laughing very quickly, but found it difficult to become "Another HP;" It takes very unique skills that the founders were blessed with.
cons:
However, eventually Bill & Dave passed on and we brought in a CEO who outright disliked everything HP was. (One example: HP had "profit sharing" and we had a good year and the rewards were quite good. The new CEO was angry at "having" to spend those monies on people and rushed to make profit sharing a thing of the past.) And we purchased, in an attempt to "be bigger" a company that also didn't fit the HP Way model. From there, the company changed almost overnight. And the change took away what was truly a unique company and replaced it with becoming just another cold, even heartless one. I left HP as a result, as did most of my coworkers. The HP I left had promised me my job back, and I followed up only to find they had a "policy change," and once you left you were not welcomed back. Instead they hired new people, people who know nothing about the old HP, and assumed all companies were the same, job security was always a concern, rewards are rare, and you felt "disposable." My heart breaks to see such a miracle disappear.

And my title here, "It's not HP anymore" was something a friend who stayed. When she heard I was thinking of coming back she said I shouldn't, and she too wished she had left but was getting closer to retiring. But like most of us "Old timers," seeing what happened to HP is, in a word, painful.
Advice to Management
Watch (At least) one documentary, I suggest "HP Origins." It does a very good job about how HP started, about Bill & Dave, and primarily, what "The HP Way" truly is. It's well-worth the 1/2 hour. Good luck to all.

Our small but mighty tech company was recently acquired by HPe. My position was eliminated in the process. My end date rolled into the first months of them acquiring us, which was odd and didn't seem necessary. We had to enroll in benefits, payroll, IT systems, only to lose them a month later when we ended. Although they provided some career transitional support, it wasnt at all at the level it should have been. Any questions we had around the process we were pushed into a generic "ask HR" email address that would get a response 3 weeks later, or not at all. Their never seemed to be anyone who knew answers or could provide help. We were constantly told to "go to links" for info. No personable feel at all. It was a terribly disconnected process and the communication was always broken. The right hand never seemed to be talking to the left. You were made to very much feel like just a number during the process and I could feel the growing curve from a small personable company to a cold tech giant company in which no one seemed to care what you did before the acquisition, or know how to help with anything. The culture started to drastically shift, which was sad. The IT onboarding process on our first day was terrible and I have never been treated so rude by IT people. After leaving, I was told my completion bonus would go in on a certain date, and it didnt. I spent hours back and forth with HR trying to get answers as to why that changed and was not communicated to me. On top of that, noone from HPE confirmed with the state the information I submitted for unemployment benefits, so I was left waiting for a response, and finally the state took it in their own hands to confirm the info with me so I could get my eligibility. I was very unimpressed that such a large company like HPe would not have a handle on taking care of the people affected by an acquisition layoff. Once again...they made you feel irrelevant and like a number. I expected more from a company of this size. It has nothing to do with getting laid off. It happens, its the corporate world we live in,but its about ethics, taking care of the people, and making the offboarding experience as easy as possible for those leaving. Didnt happen. It was a circus over there from the second they acquired us, and it was starting to ruin the great culture our company had into place before HPe came in and swallowed us up. I hope they can improve this experience for future situations like this, because I have such a bad taste in my mouth from HPe, I dont think I would ever work there or recommend them to other peers. Whats sad too, is they bought us because they couldn't beat us. I just hope they can carry the legacy and incredible work we did. There is a reason we were number one in our industry. If someone is being promoted, you have to compensate them fairly, not ignore their pleas. Also, pay people for all of their closed opportunities. It's not my job to calculate my commission check yet I was continuously doing the math and having to be "rightfully paid" for checks months late. This is why nobody stays here longer than a year or so here. You just get sick of the mistreatment and lack of progression.
